newsitem.title: USA: Consumer confidence hits six-year high.
newsitem.headline: Consumer confidence hits six-year high.

text.p: Consumers' confidence in the economy hit a six-year high in August and their expectations for the next six months also rose, the Conference Board said Tuesday.
"Confidence levels about both current and future business conditions are higher now than at any time since early 1990," said Lynn Franco, Associate Director of the board's consumer research centre.
The Conference Board, a private business research organisation, said its index of consumer confidence rose to 109.4 in August from a revised reading of 107.0 in July.
"The surge in confidence in July, coupled with the August advance, suggests that consumer attitudes may be on an upward trend after remaining stagnant for more than a year," Franco said.
The expectations component of the August index rose to 97.7 from a revised 95.0 in July and the current conditions component was up at 126.9 from a revised 125.0 in July.
The index is based on a survey of 5,000 households conducted monthly for the board by NFO Research Inc. of Greenwich, Conn.
Almost 29 percent of the surveyed families said current business conditions were "good," up from less than 28 percent in July, the board said.
The proportion of consumers expecting business conditions to deteriorate fell to 7.4 percent from 8.2 percent in July, it added.
The percentage of families expecting their incomes to go up increased to nearly 24 percent from 21 percent in July.
The board said confidence rose in most regions of the country compared with readings at this time last year.
The Pacific Coast rose most dramatically, climbing nearly 24 percent from the June, July or August figures in 1995, the board said.

The only region showing a decline was the Rocky Mountain area, down about 3 percent, the board said, although it added that confidence levels in that area continue to be "at comparatively high levels."
Employment was the one area where the survey showed mixed expectations, the board said.

Twenty-three percent of families said jobs were "hard to get," up slightly from July, while 15 percent said they expect more jobs to become available during the next six months, up from 14 percent in July.
